627599583.name: Delightful and historic
627599583.author: a TripAdvisor user
627599583.reviewBody: If you\'re in the area, make sure to spend an afternoon wandering the beautiful plazas and colourful streets of Tlaxcala\'s historical centre. Tlaxcala is a small, tranquil and clean town, no traffic, no hustle bustle. People are friendly and helpful. There is a weekend market on the Xicohtencatl Plaza next to the central plaza with local artisanal items from cocoa and mole to woollen goods.

612105650.name: Many old building, beautiful to a gringo who sees few in the USA
612105650.author: a TripAdvisor user
612105650.reviewBody: I marvel at the beauty of old building such as those in this Mexican city.  I see few to no old buildings in my hometown of Charlotte thus I loved this opportunity to view the old structures and found many restaurants with lots of charm.  The churches and museums, as well at the state government building were also impressive.

582670252.name: Charming small town
582670252.author: a TripAdvisor user
582670252.reviewBody: Shaded zocalo and separate park, restaurants, flowers, and steeped in history .  Up a path to the Cathedral great views and also a bullring!  Museums, churches (the man paroquia one closed due to Sept 17 earthquake).  Archaeological zones and Basilica de Ocotlan nearby - really nice place to stop and relax.

555687585.name: Just a wonderful place to spend time.
555687585.author: a TripAdvisor user
555687585.reviewBody: There are restaurants everywhere but the true cuisine can only be found from the street and park vendors. Fresh tamales...mmmmm. Quesadillas with extreme flavors. Tlaxacala retains more of the Spanish cooking than any other state in Mexico. The place is clean, safe, family orientated, and easy on the pocket book.\n\nDo not leave without seeing the murals in the city building. Breathtaking artistry

401109632.name: Beautiful
401109632.author: a TripAdvisor user
401109632.reviewBody: Nice place for a walk, the trees are beautiful. Lots of restaurants near by. Very secure and clean place.

391324438.name: Great place for walking and sight seen
391324438.author: a TripAdvisor user
391324438.reviewBody: Very nice place for walk, enjot architecture, people are very kind, SAFE place.\nFood in downtown is regular, nothing special to comment, go to the Tourism office and take some printed info.\nTake the Bus City Tour.

384786969.name: Tlaxcalas Legilative Palace.
384786969.author: a TripAdvisor user
384786969.reviewBody: The Legislative Palace of Tlaxcala is located in the Historic Center at the end of Juarez Park. It was once the trolley bus station where Mules pulled trolleys on tracks for a distance of six or seven miles. \n The building has a stain glass ceiling and a Mural containing the Heraldic Shields of the States 60 Municipalities. No Admission fee, just ask permission from the guard at the front gate. Sometimes they have painting and historic exhibits.

369305517.name: Definitely worth the time
369305517.author: a TripAdvisor user
369305517.reviewBody: The Centro Historico of Tlaxcala is one of the most compact in the country; a pleasant walk through a historic centre of great significance. Even if you\'re not "into" Mexican history, the importance of the city and state as a staging point for Cortez etc., you\'ll enjoy a walk through this pleasant downtown, with one of the country\'s oldest cathedrals and bullfighting rings, the amazing murals in the municipal building and some very good restaurants. My wife and I were there last August on a day trip. We hired local resident Bob Cox as a guide and I\'d highly recommending doing so, especially if you are a Canadian (us), American or European and only somewhat knowledgeable about the history of the state. But even Mexicans, many of whom might not know the role the city and state played in Mexico\'s history, would benefit from Bob\'s rich knowledge of the area.

360866552.name: Untouristy
360866552.author: a TripAdvisor user
360866552.reviewBody: There was a lot more traffic since my last visit and there were ongoing roadworks on several streets that made it worse. This is one of the less visited colonial capitals by foreigners and it is certainly worth a day or two, especially considering its importance in the story of the conquest. To get away from the hustle and bustle walk up the cobbled hill to the cathedral, possibly the oldest church in the country, and which has a beautiful mud\u00e9jar style ceiling and the pulpit from which the first sermon in the New World was supposedly preached.

645384243.name: This is a must-see!
645384243.author: a TripAdvisor user
645384243.reviewBody: The Goverment Palace, built in the 16th Century, is a mixture of Arabic architecture, Spanish and pre-Hispanic reminiscences.  In the interior of the main patio are 450 square meters of colorful frescoes describing the history of the Tlaxcalan people, painted by Desiderio Hern\u00e1ndez Xochitiotzin, the last of the great Mexican muralists. This is a must-see on your visit to Tlaxcala!

634479580.name: Same as the murals
634479580.author: a TripAdvisor user
634479580.reviewBody: The murals are in the Palacio de gobierno--telling the story of Tlaxcala.  They are well worthwhile.  Plus Hernan Cortes lived here before he went to conquer Mexico City.

627602430.name: Fascinating local history mural
627602430.author: a TripAdvisor user
627602430.reviewBody: This is the same as the listing called Murals of the Government Palace. It is free to enter the building. There is a series of murals starting with the ancient history of the area and going up to modern times. The ground floor is pre-hispanic and the 1st floor shows the history once the Spaniards came to Tlaxcala. The murals are numbered making it easier to follow in sequence and understand the unfolding of local history.

620305815.name: Centuries of Mexican history in front of you
620305815.author: a TripAdvisor user
620305815.reviewBody: Tlaxcala\'s Government Palace is a beautiful building that keeps a secret inside: there are wonderful murals depicting Mexico\'s centuries of history. Entrance is free and you will not regret investing your time in looking at the colorful and detailed scenes.\n\nIf you come from abroad you could hire a guide to explain the murals\' sequence to you, or you can read or research a bit in advance so you make the most of this experience.

582668487.name: Excellent murals in Government Palace
582668487.author: a TripAdvisor user
582668487.reviewBody: There is a 2nd listing for this same place.  It is free, local artist illustrated the local history - such talent! Goes up the stairs and beyond - incredible detail.  Open all day \'every day", photos allowed.

420990310.name: Exquisite historical murals
420990310.author: a TripAdvisor user
420990310.reviewBody: Free and only takes a few minutes to visit . . . well, our few minutes stretched into 30, but we loved it.  Fascinating overview of the history of the area.  I didn\'t understand most of it until we hired a guide the following day and found out the history behind some of the murals.  I wish I had done a little reading first.  The photos here are very good so I didn\'t add any new ones.

625130762.name: Interesante caminata de paisaje animal
625130762.author: a TripAdvisor user
625130762.reviewBody: Un destino diferente cerca del coraz\u00f3n de Tlaxcala. Ideal para que los ni\u00f1os conozcan nuevos animales y los adultos nos asombremos con los hu\u00e9spedes del zool\u00f3gico a un precio accesible. Se puede llegar en transporte p\u00fablico desde Tlaxcala centro.

604442865.name: Buena opci\u00f3n de paseo familiar
604442865.author: a TripAdvisor user
604442865.reviewBody: Esta muy limpio y los animales est\u00e1n en muy buen estado. Es una excelente opci\u00f3n para paseo familiar, la verdad es que supero mis expectativas! Y s\u00faper econ\u00f3mico. Lo recomiendo!

563923264.name: Un buen lugar para visitar en este peque\u00f1o estado del centro de M\u00e9xico.
563923264.author: a TripAdvisor user
563923264.reviewBody: Es un lugar bonito muy espacioso y donde tienen bien a los animales en exhibici\u00f3n, aunque hay espacios vac\u00edos, yo viaje pues para ver la novedad que promovieron en la televisi\u00f3n un leoncito blanco nacido ah\u00ed, y me lleve la decepci\u00f3n que no fueron claros con la fecha pues dijeron que hasta febrero podr\u00eda ser visto y cr\u00e9anme no  fui el \u00fanico decepcionado, cientos de personas llegaron al lugar con la misma ilusi\u00f3n. Al ver el par de jaguares tan hermosos que tienen en exhibici\u00f3n se me pas\u00f3 el mal sabor los tienen en un excelente espacio para ser admirados, tambi\u00e9n tienen otros felinos y muchas otras especies. En general es un buen lugar muy econ\u00f3micos sus precios y los medios de transporte hay muchos muchos desde el centro de Tlaxcala ciudad, tambi\u00e9n puedes ir en autob\u00fas desde la cd. de M\u00e9xico, viajando en segunda clase y bajando en la Polic\u00eda Federal que esta justo frente al zool\u00f3gico. Es un lugar recomendable como paseo familiar o si te gusta hacer fotograf\u00eda.

513796513.name: Excelente lugar!!!!
513796513.author: a TripAdvisor user
513796513.reviewBody: Sin duda alguna super\u00f3 mis expectativas....ya que es un lugar s\u00faper econ\u00f3mico...con amplias instalaciones y muy limpias.... gran variedad de especies....juegos y zonas para preparar alimentos!!! Lugar ampliamente recomendado !!!!

510594078.name: una visita casi obligatoria
510594078.author: a TripAdvisor user
510594078.reviewBody: El zoologico no e smuy grande, pero la entrada es bastante comoda, los ni\u00f1os se divierten, tiene zona de juegos infnatiles y un peque\u00f1o laguito para remar, pero lo que m\u00e1s me sorprendio es que tienen 3 leones blancos y esos estan ya declarados como extintos

489362657.name: Un hermoso lugar
489362657.author: a TripAdvisor user
489362657.reviewBody: Conoci al zoologico de Altiplano con dos amigos. Fue una hermosa experiencia. Hay muchos animales y un bonito lago.

487662410.name: Zool\u00f3gico bueno, bonito y barato (bbb)
487662410.author: a TripAdvisor user
487662410.reviewBody: Recomendable para pasar un d\u00eda en familia, sobre todo si tienen hijos y no quieres gastar mucho. Las instalaciones est\u00e1 en buen estado, puedes recorrer todo el zool\u00f3gico a pie e introducir alimentos o bebidas aunque los precios de la comida adentro no eran altos. La entrada fue de $20 pesos adultos y $10 ni\u00f1os. Les recomiendo comprar las v\u00edsceras de animalitos que venden afuera de la entrada son muy bonitas, econ\u00f3micas, funcionales y sobre todo terminan siendo un gran recuerdo para los ni\u00f1os por tan s\u00f3lo $10 pesos.

482732300.name: Un Zool\u00f3gico, con atracciones padrisimas, para toda la familia!!!
482732300.author: a TripAdvisor user
482732300.reviewBody:
Los invito que vayan al Zoológico del Altiplano, es para toda la familia  haces un recorrido muy padre viendo los animales, para mi el ver la pareja de Leones Blancos estuvo muy padre, como los tres osos que tienen, y muchos animales más. 

Ademas que puedas remar en el lago que tienen, disfrutas el paisaje y te diviertes con los pequeños. Tienen una Zona de juegos para los peques que la verdad están muy bien.  Y tienes la oportunidad de hacer in Picnic con la familia!!!

Vayan la van a pasar super divertidos en familia!!!

424114868.name: Buen Zool\u00f3gico para pasar una tarde de Picnic con la familia
424114868.author: a TripAdvisor user
424114868.reviewBody: El precio es muy accesible para llevar a toda la familia, es un lugar muy bien pensado, sin embargo algunas \u00e1reas est\u00e1n descuidadas, podr\u00e1s ver muy de cerca a las Jirafas, leones, tigres y un serpentario. Cuenta con un lago y un \u00e1rea de juegos.

660896572.name: Excellent basilica
660896572.author: a TripAdvisor user
660896572.reviewBody: Nice facade and patio, but gourgeuos interior decoration, the sacristia and baptistry are incredible.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

659462702.name: Pilgrimage to the sanctuary
659462702.author: a TripAdvisor user
659462702.reviewBody: The basilica is located up a steep hill lined with ceramic tiles of biblical scenes, so it feels like a pilgrimage.  But if there\'s one church to be visited in all Mexico, this is it.  Despite being covered with scaffolding, the church reveals its late baroque finery and unusual polygonal brickwork.  The interior is an explosion of carvings covered with gold leaf, and there are paintings of the Stations of the Cross to admire.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

645390922.name: Beautiful but be prepared for a long, up-hill climb
645390922.author: a TripAdvisor user
645390922.reviewBody: Situated on a hill above the city of Tlaxcala, the Sanctuary of Our Lady of Ocotlan, built in the 16th century, is one of the main Catholic pilgrimage sites in Mexico.  It\'s a long up-hill climb to get there but, if you\'re a fan of beautiful churches with Mexican Baroque architecture, or a believer in miracles, it might be worth the trip.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

641348214.name: A Beautiful Basilica
641348214.author: a TripAdvisor user
641348214.reviewBody: We walked up the hill path to this very old church still filled with beautiful objects.  It sits at the top and overlooks the bull fighting ring.  The church needs a lot of work but appears to be filled with pride while overlooking the wonderful colonial-like city of Tlaxcala.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

636763365.name: The Puebla version of the Virgin of Guadalupe
636763365.author: a TripAdvisor user
636763365.reviewBody: This miracle happened about 10 years after the Virgin appears to Juan Diego near Mexico City.  This site was not very visited, but had its own charming legend, beautiful basilica, and fabulous "dressing" chapel.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

618053106.name: Wedding
618053106.author: a TripAdvisor user
618053106.reviewBody: I went here with a friend while there was a wedding in process, with tons of armed guards, whatever that means. Recognizing us as the harmless tourists we were, they let us enter. Beautiful church, beautiful bride, beautiful flowers

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

514376633.name: Nice for a quick Visit - Attention to detail within... You\'ll be surprised.
514376633.author: a TripAdvisor user
514376633.reviewBody: As you get there, you won\'t think much about it.... once you go in, you\'ll be wow\'ed!\n\nThe gold plated walls and attention to detail is amazing!

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

468195251.name: Beautiful Church
468195251.author: a TripAdvisor user
468195251.reviewBody:
You need to visit the chapel behind the altar.  There are some beautiful paintings plus a table that must be seen.  The top of the table is from the trunk of a tree (one solid piece).  Imagine the number of years the tree was. 

There is a story that when the statute of our Lady was first brought in, the priest was in favor of the statue of San Lorenzo.  The priest would place San Lorenzo higher than Mary, but every morning. ..the statues were reversed.  The priest thinking that someone was doing this, he locked the statute of Our Lady in a trunk.  To his surprise, our Lady was above San Lorenzo. 

One of the keepers there, speaks the original language that Juan Diego spoke.  He is a walking encyclopedia.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

427974479.name: Another beautiful church
427974479.author: a TripAdvisor user
427974479.reviewBody: Mexico is full of beautiful churches. The history of this one is very interesting and is displayed on the walls

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

411089410.name: Beatutiful Church
411089410.author: a TripAdvisor user
411089410.reviewBody: Only about 10 years after the apparition of Our Lady of Guadalupe in Mexico City, that Our Lady of Ocotlan appeared to Juan Diego (no relation to the Juan Diego of OLG). Since there was a plague she provided him a miraculous spring so the Indians could drink and be cured. The celebrations is held on January 1st and in May. The church is beautiful and nearby a few blocks away and down a steep set of stairs, you can go to the spring and drink the water as well as take some home with you. They have a little gift store as well.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

386264542.name: Muy bonita
386264542.author: a TripAdvisor user
386264542.reviewBody: Very interesting visit. The place also offers a great view of popocatepetl... a must seen in tlaxcala.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

369948867.name: Is a part of the tour
369948867.author: a TripAdvisor user
369948867.reviewBody: While riding the Tranvia Tour you can visit this place. A very important church, a Basilica with a festivity once a year. Really big, well preserved and with a view.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

327147084.name: Stunning views
327147084.author: a TripAdvisor user
327147084.reviewBody:
Ocotlan is must Wether in puebla or tlaxcala. Built in the 1500 the church was finished by Indians. 

The virgen appeared to an Indian  who in the end took the statue to the current temple.  Sea shells are theme here, where the biggest one houses the main shrine.

A must!!

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

315299147.name: BASILICA DE OCOTLAN
315299147.author: a TripAdvisor user
315299147.reviewBody: Basilica de Ocotlan is beautiful inside,visited a while back.We stopped here foe mass. We were able to buy same water from the spring that the Virgin Mary in 1541 showed herself to Juan Diego Bernadino and told him this water will cure the village people for the pague they had.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

298349760.name: Beautiful, still functional church.
298349760.author: a TripAdvisor user
298349760.reviewBody: This was a stop on the tour we took on a bus from the Constitution Square.  It is a beautiful church.  There was a Quincinera going on at the time so we were able to see a bit of culture.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

277211490.name: Over the top
277211490.author: a TripAdvisor user
277211490.reviewBody: One of the most elaborate baroque churches we\'ve seen in Mexico, which is saying a lot! Several artists were working on scaffolding, restoring the gilding around the altar. We were there the week after a fiesta of the Virigin of Ocotlan, and pilgrims were praying to her large, beautifully dressed statue to be cured of their ills. It was a moving experience.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

275091447.name: The interior is wonderful, the exterior is perplexing
275091447.author: a TripAdvisor user
275091447.reviewBody:
This is one of the most revered Sanctuaries of Mexico. The name comes from the Ocotlán hill, on the top of which the Sanctuary is perched. The church was built after the appearance of the Virgin Mary to a local countryman in 1541, but the present building dates from the 18th century. The church is extolled as one of the best examples of Mexican Baroque architecture; actually, the interior is absolutely wonderful, whereas the exterior looks rather “pop” and perplexing. Anyway, the church is definitely worth a visit. Plan to stay about half an hour.

The interior of the building has a very simple structure (a nave and a small transept), but its decoration is extraordinarily rich and beautiful, actually one of the richest I have seen in Mexico. The apse and the two transepts are fully covered (wall-to-wall and floor-to-ceiling) with Churrigueresque altars, sculpted and gilded. The walls of the nave are taken up by 6 enormous paintings encased in molded and gilded frames. Any other available space is filled with ornaments. The whole appears harmonious and well-proportioned; at the same time, it is absolutely impressive. Looking at this interior justifies the trip to Tlaxcala.

The exterior is eye-catching but, in certain sense, odd and perplexing. Actually, the structure of the building is very elegant, but a questionable use of colours debases the brilliant work of the architects. The façade, profusely sculpted in Churrigueresque style, was smothered with a layer of white plaster, and the same fate occurred to the summit of the beautiful bell-towers. The sense of drama, typical of the baroque scenarios, has completely been lost, and the façade now looks kinda a gigantic wedding-cake adorned with white figurines. I have been told that this unfortunate arrangement was made out of necessity, since the façade was not sculpted, but fabricated with juxtaposed bricks, like a "lego"; the assemblage was then plastered and finally whitewashed. 

The sanctuary is on the top of a hill, less than 1 mile from the centre. It is possible to go there on foot, but it's more practical to take one of the frequent micro-buses marked Ocotlán, (6.50 Pesos = 0.47 US $); they will drop you at the church. In front of the church there are stalls catering to the visitors and selling souvenirs.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

263150016.name: Beautiful ceilings
263150016.author: a TripAdvisor user
263150016.reviewBody: The town of Tlaxcala was a nice place for lunch too, and just up the hill was the Basilica, which was good to see.  Fabulous gold ceilings, and free entry.  You have to ask one of the church wardens if you want to go into the famous dome, which is definitely worth a look

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

255239607.name: Highly recommended !
255239607.author: a TripAdvisor user
255239607.reviewBody: This is one of the most beautiful Baroque Bas\u00edlicas that you have to visit. And at the\nback part of the Basilica, there is a small and exclusive chapel called "cofrad\u00eda de la Virgen", you have to try to visit this chapel, is "very beautiful"

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

239154911.name: A great hike
239154911.author: a TripAdvisor user
239154911.reviewBody: It\'s a good, healthy hike up to the hill this church is on.  Great views of the city and Popocatepetl.  The church is beautiful inside, although there were many scaffolds up when we visited for restoration.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

233340710.name: Going for Baroque!
233340710.author: a TripAdvisor user
233340710.reviewBody: This lovely,  and extremely well maintained church, located on z slight rise a brief stroll from the Center, was as frothy and as pretty as a wedding cake, which was appropriate as a wedding was going on while we were there. This was pretty cool, seeing the church being used!

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

215140240.name: Worth a visit.
215140240.author: a TripAdvisor user
215140240.reviewBody: Did this trip in 2009. This was one of the Basilicas on the agenda and the place of the Miraculous waters. It is sought after by visitors because of the healing powers contained therein.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

182170019.name: Place of Miraculous Waters.
182170019.author: a TripAdvisor user
182170019.reviewBody: According to Legend in 1541 Juan Diego an Indigenous peasant while searching for firewood in a pine forest was confronted by a beautiful lady next to a spring of clear water who told him drink this water and it will cure you of all ills, even if its only one drop. There was an epidemic of smallpox going on  at the time and Juan shared the water with many and cured them.\n The Sanctuary and Basilica of the Virgen of Ocotlan was built here and the Chapel of  the well of Holy Water.  Considered one of the most important Temples inthe State, the Front Facade made of brick and mortar in Baroque Style . Decorated with many Religious Icons  and themes you can see the figure of the Virgen, twelve apostles, Saint Francis of Asis, Saint Joseph, six archangels and the four Doctors of Religion, Saint Ambrose, Saint Jerome, Saint Augustine and SaintGregory. Inside the Temple we find very ornate panels featuring various Saints but the Main feature is Our Lady of Ocotlan. Sometimes it\'s permitted to enter the Virgens dressing room which has many paintings of her meeting with Juan Diego... Not permitted if Mass is going on.   The Chapel of the Well is also free entrance and if you take a container, or you can purchase one at the site they will gladly give you water . There is a souvenir shop there as well. The Well has murals depicting biblical aquatic scenes. \n There is Public transport that goes from downtown to the Shrine but it can be gotten to by hiking to the site, a little strenous but not bad if you take your time,

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

174582591.name: Exuberant Baroque building
174582591.author: a TripAdvisor user
174582591.reviewBody: Interesting and well preserved building, obviously a place for worship for locals and other Mexicans. We tried to see their big attraction (paintings behind the altar by an indigenous artist but there was always a Mass going on... must be nice.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

152381927.name: Over the top and worth a visit!
152381927.author: a TripAdvisor user
152381927.reviewBody: The Basilica de Ocotlan shouldn\'t be missed if you visit Tlaxcala.  This is considered one of Mexico\'s most spectacular churches.  The white domes can be seen from town.  The inside of the church is extremely baroque and a feast for the eyes.  I would definitely visit it again and recommend it to my friends.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

147562982.name: Tlaxcala.  Its a Miracle!
147562982.author: a TripAdvisor user
147562982.reviewBody:
If you are planning a visit to Talaxcala, you might place this plan under review.  We were drawn to this small Mexican city primarily by the report in the Lonely Planet Guide, Mexico City, published in 2008.  As far as I can tell, this is still the benchmark travel guide for this city in English.   A couple articles on the internet backed up this point of view, so I thought it important to file an alternative report.

    In the LP guide Daniel Schecter writes of a small city with a well preserved colonial center.  The implication is that the administrative center of Mexico has moved on, but the colonial buildings of Tlaxcala are representative of a larger presence two hundred years ago.  I’m here to tell you that the vice-regal administrative buildings are smaller than those in Coyocan, sort of squat and unimpressive, albeit in a peaceful sort of way.  
     We were seduced into staying on the zocalo.  While it is tranquil much of the time, and has its fair share of greenery, compared to other Mexican towns, this zocalo is no reason per se to spend a night in Talaxcala.  We spent three!  By comparison, Coyocan and Puebla each boast a zocalo that will take your breath away.  In Talaxcala expect no grand fountains, amazing plantings, monumental churches or other palatial structures on the zocalo.  
     The zocalo is an integral part of the community, though.  It hosts exercise class in the morning and on Friday night we danced to a live band with the older seniors by the central gazebo.
     The local museums are pathetic.  Unless you consider three small, poorly executed Frida Kahlo paintings a treasure to be sought.
     
    One of the main reasons we came to Tlaxcala was a quest for the pilgrimage church.   The Virgen de Ocotlan appeared here in 1541 to a Tlaxcala (Indian) named Juan Diego Bernardino.   Little finds it way into the English speaking press regarding this encounter other than (erroneously) the Basilica de Ocotlan is located on the site of this meeting.  Why did she appear?  What did she say to Juan Diego?   And why is this encounter less important than the one that occurred (ten years earlier) on a hill named Guadalupe on the north shore of Lake Texcoco?
      On our first full day we set out to visit this pilgrimage church.  Sr Schecter says it is one of “Mexico’s most spectacular.”  I was pumped.  

     In deference to my sweetie’s hurt foot, we took a taxi up to the Basilica de Ocotlan.  Immediately things went south.  The taxi fare was 40 P.  I attempted to pay with a 100 (about 9 USD).  No hay cambio.  In fact, none of the little shops that sold food and knick knacks were willing to change this small note …even if I bought something.  Bizarre and not exactly a harbinger of good things to come.  The driver trusted us to pay him when we returned to the hotel.  Jose is OK.

     So we visited the church.  Our first impression was, “This is the most beautiful church?!!  NOT!”   The outside is quite unimpressive…it could be mistaken for a gazillion other Mexican churches.  The single vault boasts a tall gilded altar and a similarly gilded chapel, but nothing seemed all that impressive.  The Virgin Mary above the altar and behind glass may be the virgin statue that was found in the famous encounter in 1541, but this is not entirely clear.  I love old churches.  See some of my other reviews.  This church was simply unlovable.  

     We tried to walk around the church to get a view of the supposedly lovely exterior and had a near death experience with a garbage truck, all to no avail.  There are no  good views of the church from the exterior.  
      Boy, were we disappointed.  I’m not exactly Roman Catholic, but I believe in God and get a very special feeling in most churches.  Not this one.  Que triste.

     So we exited the main gate and the Redoubtable SKG and I began the descent to the centro.  After one block, we encountered a choice in path.  A larger dusty road to the right appeared to be the one we had taken in the taxi, but a smaller road, that headed straight down the steep hill had a sign pointing to a church.  “A few churches in the centro,” I thought to myself.  At this early morning crossroads there was a lady washing her sidewalk while her elderly father supervised.  We asked directions in our best broken Espanol,  She recommended the smaller steeper road straight ahead.  
     A block down this precipitous calle we had a chance to confirm her information with a lady sweeping her driveway.  At the bottom of the long block we noted a sign directing traffic to the left.  Still, our consultant said, “Derecha.”  with the appropriate hand signal.  The road, with a wonderful set of wide steps, meandered steeply for another two blocks, with good views of the city, such as it is.  Towards the bottom we happened upon a single blue and white ceramic dome.  

    A few steps further and we found ourselves at a small domed chapel.  A plaque on the outside informed us that the chapel of El Pocito is at the place where the Virgin appeared to Juan Diego.   The Tlaxcalas were suffering a terrible epidemic and Mary directed the indio to a well whose blessed water would save the tribe.  She also directed Juan Diego to notify the church authorities and search for a sign in the nearby forest.  The priests pried into a tree and recovered a statue of the virgin that may be the one in the basilica. 
    
   A smaller chapel had existed on this spot, but recently the local Obispo had this tidy structure erected.  The murals inside were painted by local Tlaxcala Indians.  And the water from the well is there in plastic garbage cans for you to enjoy.  
   I could barely believe our good fortune.  It was as if the Holy Spirit had a hand in bringing us to this chapel that sings with the truth of His presence. Unbeknowst to us, we had been following the steps created for the pilgrims who visit the basilica and then the chapel and the well!   The murals, picturing Mary, the Indians and conquistadores are alive with color.  And I tingled with joy as I anointed myself from the spring water.   
   Cups are provided.  On a later visit I sat with three Mexicanos of about my age.  One drank a full glass.  So I plucked up my courage and quaffed an ounce or so.  It may have changed my life.  Who knows? 
    
    Below the chapel is a park run by the ayuntamiento.  I am an out of the closet bird watcher and had hoped to see some birds here in Tlaxcala, which is safe enough to walk around in, even in the small wooded corners.   Up to this time we had seen no birds of merit.  Here we saw three species of wintering North American warblers.   On later visits I saw a few more good Mexican birds.  There are benches in the park and it is peaceful place to rest.
    A walk down the hill from the basilica is recommended.  However, the park and chapel can be accessed from  Xicohtencatl, the second street over from the zocalo.  Take Xico to the end, turn right where the road Ts at the pink church. And veer left in one block.  
   And Vaya con Dios.

If you speak Spanish or run into a Mexican tourist who speaks English (this peaceful town has a substantial allure to middle class Mexicans from the DF) you will find that the sacred well is no secret at all.  Why it is not found in tourist literature in English is a complete mystery.

Jeff

Birds of the Parque de Ocotlan 

House Finch
Gray Towhee
Black tailed Gnatcatcher
Townsends Warbler
Audubon’s Warbler
Prothonotary Warbler
Bendire’s Thrasher
So House Wren
Gray Breasted Wood Wren
Hooded Oriole
Great Tailed Grackle

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

133131458.name: A Beautifully Restored Church; A Great Market Town Every Friday
133131458.author: a TripAdvisor user
133131458.reviewBody: Spending a Friday in Ocotlan is a must if you are in Oaxaca. The interior of the church was restored thanks to its patron, the artist Rodulfo Morelos. Both inside and out, the church is certainly the centerpiece of Ocotlan. Friday is market day in Ocotlan. As I have been to a number of the local town markets in the Valley of Oaxaca, the one here is one of my favorites. The sights, sounds, and smells of a traditional market are all present.  From fruit and vegetables, to housewares and crafts, you can find it all in the fairly compact central square area. Most interesting are the people selling turkeys and other poultry. Many opportunities exist to have lunch or a snack at the market. Take a local bus to and from Ocotlan. It\'s an easy trip and you can combine it with stops at the black pottery village (San Bartolo) or San Martin where many of the alebrijes (carved wood fantasy animals) are fabricated. Plan a whole day to head in this direction out of Oaxaca.

itemReviewed.name: Basilica de Nuestra Senora de Ocotlan

401108615.name: Best tour
401108615.author: a TripAdvisor user
401108615.reviewBody: It\'s a short and nice tour. The guides are great and they explain the basic stuff you should know about the places they take you to. The best is the Basilica of Nuestra Se\u00f1ora de Ocotl\u00e1n.

address.streetAddress: Plaza de la Constitucion, Centro Tlaxcala frente la oficina de correos de Mexico en contra esquina del Hotel Posada San Francisco

369669349.name: Interesting new experiences
369669349.author: a TripAdvisor user
369669349.reviewBody: We never thought Tlaxcala was like what we saw, very clean, well maintained, small city, cute. It was a pleasant surprise to notice this place, excellent for a weekend and this tour drives you to the important points with a certified fun guide. Besides you can have tastings of mole, bread, pulque. Well invested time and money.

address.streetAddress: Plaza de la Constitucion, Centro Tlaxcala frente la oficina de correos de Mexico en contra esquina del Hotel Posada San Francisco

665579510.name: Beautiful Parish church
665579510.author: a TripAdvisor user
665579510.reviewBody: The Parish church of San Andr\u00e9s Buenavista, is a church built in the shape of a boat. On the ground floor is the altar and on the upper levels you can see from its balconies a spectacular panorama, even has a room for temporary exhibitions.\nWhen you make a trip to Tlaxcala, I recommend you stop at this place, take your camera or cell phone and take flight with this building of Catholic faith that the only thing you need is ... navigate!

542094367.name: Tiny Site
542094367.author: a TripAdvisor user
542094367.reviewBody: This is a tiny site, with a small rounded pyramid. It is right on the side of the road, so very convenient for a stop if you are passing by on highway 136.

address.streetAddress: Km. 33 Carretera Federal Mexico San Felipe Sultepec

384772784.name: TECOAQUE (ZULTEPEC) ARCHEOLOGICAL ZONE
384772784.author: a TripAdvisor user
384772784.reviewBody:
Just a couple of miles North od Calpulalpan, The Zone has only been open for a few years, Several Temples have been uncovered. The site is Unique as it has a historical  background relating to the Conquest. A second wave of Spaniards consisting of Conquistadors, Tlaxcalan Warriors, African slaves, Cuban Mulatos, fifty women and 12 Children were captured and imprisoned for about 9 months and were slowly sacrificed over that time. Cortez was battling the Natives in Tenochitlan at the Time . After the Fall of the Aztec Empire Cortez discovered the event and was so enraged he sent a large battalion to the town and killed everyone.
The Natives heard he was coming and threw sacrificial bones and artifacts in shallow wells before he came in an attempt to hide the crime.  
The result of course provided a wealth of information for present day Archeologists.
The Caravan had over 500 people in it. The site recently opened a Museum with PreColombian artefacts and over 200 items from Spain that the victims had with them. The Victims were ritually eaten after the sacrifice, along with their horses, their craniams were drilled through the temples  and displayed on racks in the village center,.  Amongst the Architecture is found the Round Temple of Ehecatl the Aztec god of wind, Tezcatlipoca the Invisible god,  A tzompantli head display rack and the remains of village houses and walled streets.

address.streetAddress: Km. 33 Carretera Federal Mexico San Felipe Sultepec

333265784.name: My favorite archeologycal site in Tlaxcala
333265784.author: a TripAdvisor user
333265784.reviewBody: The most famous of sites are Cacaxtla and Xochit\u00e9catl, but I like this one better. It\'s not crowded, they have a good museum, and the constructions are well kept. I felt very peaceful in peace in this place, I even rested with my family on top of one of the pyramids all by ourselves.\nIt\'s a little far away from the City of Tlaxcala, but if you like prehispanic archeology, you may like this place.

address.streetAddress: Km. 33 Carretera Federal Mexico San Felipe Sultepec

654014542.name: First thing we went to see
654014542.author: a TripAdvisor user
654014542.reviewBody: On the Zocalo is a large building that does not advertise the fabulous murals inside, so go to the door fifty ft from right end to go in, and walls-look up and then go up the stairs. These are really good murals.

645375712.name: The murals are a must see!
645375712.author: a TripAdvisor user
645375712.reviewBody: The beautiful murals in the Government Palace, which portray the history of the area, are definitely a must-see when visiting Tlaxacla.

641348530.name: Marvels of Art
641348530.author: a TripAdvisor user
641348530.reviewBody: These murals are a must see.  They are a colorful and captivating history lesson.  Their location in the zocalo makes them easy to find and is a must see experience.

634479150.name: Great murals
634479150.author: a TripAdvisor user
634479150.reviewBody: These murals and the Palacio are the same site.  These murals tell the story of Tlaxcala--they were never defeated by the Aztecs--the joined up with Cortez, they were the first converts in the new world to Christianity.  All in bright colors--a local muralist.

618052567.name: Fantastic
618052567.author: a TripAdvisor user
618052567.reviewBody: I went to see these murals with a friend. Neither of us knew anything about them. They were absolutely fantastic! We were there for well over an hour, surrounded by an enthusiastic crowd that was seemingly as blown away as we were.

595414620.name: Stop by for history
595414620.author: a TripAdvisor user
595414620.reviewBody: One interesting thing about this site is that it us a working government buildings. Staffers will rush by on the way to meetings while you admire the murals. Tlaxcala is an indigenous area that was never conquered by the Aztecs. Politically astute, these folks sided with Cortez. The entire story is told on the murals.

551342681.name: Interesting...very detailed
551342681.author: a TripAdvisor user
551342681.reviewBody: Its worth the visit! The artist spent more than 40 years painting the murals (mexican history), with such detail, colors and love... you can see that in every inch of this fantastic huge paintings

536968434.name: Awesome artwork
536968434.author: a TripAdvisor user
536968434.reviewBody: If you are in town you must see this work. Rivals the work of Diego Rivera. Some very minor damage from the last earthquake but tells the history of Tlaxcala. Must have taken years to paint.

514375385.name: This is a MUST, for art lovers.
514375385.author: a TripAdvisor user
514375385.reviewBody: Trying getting there early morning and have breakfast in the beautiful, tranquil plaza.  Time goes by slower there and you can really take in the feeling of Tlaxcala while there.  The buildings are beautiful but the murals are SO beautiful and lively that you will cherish every moment there.  It is important to listen to the people giving the tour... there is so many details that have history, that it is worth while to take the time to do so.

493126485.name: Fabulous!
493126485.author: a TripAdvisor user
493126485.reviewBody: The murals in the government palace are great! Allow time to appreciate them. Definitely bring a camera to take pictures.

488071823.name: Important to understand the conquest of Mexico with the eyes of main supporters of spanish conquers.
488071823.author: a TripAdvisor user
488071823.reviewBody: Listening and watching the colorful paintings and Murals of the goverment palace , will be more easy to understand the reasons that did that Tlaxcala joined the spanish conquers in their fight with aztecas.

431052987.name: Simply amazing
431052987.author: a TripAdvisor user
431052987.reviewBody: Came upon these murals by chance. Wanted to see the old building and found these. Colorful depiction of the Mayan/Aztec (?) world as presented by a contemporary artist in the Mexican muralist tradition.  We did not hire the local guide. Should have done so. Worth the visit.

427974712.name: Must visit
427974712.author: a TripAdvisor user
427974712.reviewBody: History of a truly unique town and Mexico in glorious technicolor! A must visit. Talk to the resident historian - he\'s a lovely man who knows everything

418961376.name: Amazing history of Mexico and the state of Tlaxcala in one place
418961376.author: a TripAdvisor user
418961376.reviewBody: I can\'t say enough about the murals at the government palace.  We had a guide on the day after to explained many of the scenes we saw painted in the murals.  The history of Tlaxcala and Cholula are somewhat bloody before the Spanish ever arrived, and the scenes in the murals depict pre-columbian events to the conquest by Spain up to the Revolution.  Its a quick visit and a must see if you are in the town center.

401096320.name: Just ok
401096320.author: a TripAdvisor user
401096320.reviewBody: nice building... But the murals are not impressive. Go if you don\'t have nothing else to do. Take a little time to see everything

400832217.name: Amazing!!!!
400832217.author: a TripAdvisor user
400832217.reviewBody: I\u00b4m proud of my country ancient history, but Tlaxcala is simply amazing. You can see what I told you visiting the "Palacio de Gobierno", a government building where you can learn about how "tlaxcaltecas" build the foundations of M\u00e9xico trough the "mural" that is a big wall plenty of colorfull pictures beginig since the conqueror to the Mexico independence war... I hope you enjoy it

369674936.name: Small walls but full of information
369674936.author: a TripAdvisor user
369674936.reviewBody: If you go early in the morning you can watch the whole place without the crowd. The murals have a sequence so look for the beginning in order to have a better idea of the work and the history of Tlaxcala.

360865613.name: Colourful
360865613.author: a TripAdvisor user
360865613.reviewBody: I wouldn\'t rate this the top attraction in Tlaxcala (the cathedral, regional museum and church of Nossa Se\u00f1ora de Ocotlan) are far more interesting. The murals are certain ly colourful, by a minor member of the Mexican muralist school and painted over a period of over thirty years.\nI read Spanish, so got enough from them, without the service of a guide. A party of students was there with a (Spanish) guide during my visit: I am not sure if he is the same one who guides in English, but he knew enough to give an overview of the story of the Tlaxcalans and their partnership with Cortes against the Triple Alliance.

335145292.name: Must view
335145292.author: a TripAdvisor user
335145292.reviewBody: You will be amazed by the vibrant details. Go with a guide otherwise you will miss the finer points.

333192015.name: Learn Tlaxcala\'s history in an hour
333192015.author: a TripAdvisor user
333192015.reviewBody: You can read or get a tour guide to tell you the story of this State with beautiful murals that represents the story from indigenous people all the way to "modern" times.

318138468.name: Fabulous Murals in the Government Palace.
318138468.author: a TripAdvisor user
318138468.reviewBody: We hired a guide who explained the significance of the paintings which describe the history of the town of Tlaxcala and the relationship of it\'s indigenous population both with the Aztecs and with Cortez. \nThe entrance is free. We did pay our wonderful guide $150.00 pesos.

310646795.name: Incredible murals
310646795.author: a TripAdvisor user
310646795.reviewBody: I located these murals in another building in Tlaxcala in an earlier review. No problem. The capital city of the state of Tlaxcala is small and easily walkable. You\'ll have lots to see. But this is a must see. We\'ve traveled all over Mexico - which in many ways is the land of murals (Diego Rivera\'s image is on the country\'s 500 peso notes) - and I think this is the best I\'ve seen. But there\'s a lot more to see in this lovely old city, in this charming state.

298348983.name: Excellent murals and an excellent guide.
298348983.author: a TripAdvisor user
298348983.reviewBody: The murals are absolutely beautiful and tell the history of Tlaxcala.  And Mizraim is an excellent guide for the murals, so ask for him.

292966776.name: Unexpected surpirse
292966776.author: a TripAdvisor user
292966776.reviewBody: A complete depiction of Tlaxcalan and Mexican history. All the walls are covered in a myriad of colours and modern brushstrokes. Beautiful!

277210492.name: Free attraction on the zocalo
277210492.author: a TripAdvisor user
277210492.reviewBody: Brightly painted murals right inside the palacio on the central plaza. Benches available to sit and relax while viewing the murals.

261446036.name: Amazing!!
261446036.author: a TripAdvisor user
261446036.reviewBody: We went to visit the palace and there are tour guides that can explain the history of the murals. I was impressed with all the details each mural has. Our tourist guide spoke good English and knew the history of Tlaxcala.

259606079.name: The history of Tlaxcala in a 500 square metres painting
259606079.author: a TripAdvisor user
259606079.reviewBody:
The Government Palace, on the Zócalo, contains a very large number of “murales” which were painted in the years 1954-1994 by Desiderio Hernández Xochitiotzin, a famous Tlaxcaltecan artist now defunct. In 500 square metres he depicted the complete history of Tlaxcala, from the pre-colonial times up to the 20th century.

The murals are on the walls and the vault of the entrance hall, on the walls and the vault of the staircase leading to the second floor, and on part of the gallery of the second floor. Hundreds (if not thousands) of mythical and historical personages are represented, together with the most relevant facts of the Tlaxcala history and the uses and costumes of the primitive "nahua" population. Below the murals Xochitiotzin painted a number of cartouches containing detailed explanations of what he intended to represent. There are 77 cartouches of this kind, in Spanish language. In addition, the main historical personages hold in their hands a parchment where the feats of their lives are described. On the whole, this cycle of paintings amounts to a veritable and complete history course. 

Due to the complexity of the representation, it is not easy for a hurried tourist to understand all the details. Some familiarity with the Tlaxcala and the Mexican history is required for interpreting many scenes, and adequate knowledge of the Spanish language is needed for reading the cartouches and the parchments. It may help hiring a guide, and it may also help taking pictures to be viewed and analysed later on, at home; but the light is rather dim and taking good pictures requires quality equipment and great care.

The above difficulties should not dissuade the visitor. The paintings are absolutely enjoyable, the colour palette used by Xochitiotzin is enchanting, and many scenes can be easily understood, especially those representing the pre-columbine life and those involving well known personages (like Hernán Cortez, the Malinche, the politicians of the Mexican revolution, etc.). The style of Xochitiotzin is very different from the style of the other great Mexican muralists of the 20th century (Rivera, Orozco, Siqueiros, Bustos, Leal, etc.), since a great influence of the pre-columbine aesthetic standards is felt in his work. 

Viewing these murals is enough reason for visiting Tlaxcala. Tlaxcala is only 40 kilometres away from Puebla and is easily reached by public transportation. Buses and microbuses leave Puebla from the "Tlaxcala bus terminal", at 11th Nord and 12th Poniente; they drop you 3 blocks away from the Tlaxcala Zócalo; the trip takes about 1½ hours.

255240734.name: Beautiful work of Art
255240734.author: a TripAdvisor user
255240734.reviewBody: They told me, that the tlaxcalteca painter took 20 years\nto finish this beautiful work, you can get a tourist guide that explains the meaning of each part of the murals.

244869788.name: A must see mural of the history of Mexico
244869788.author: a TripAdvisor user
244869788.reviewBody: The large murals of the Tlaxala Palacio de Gobierno (bordering the Zocalo) are not only beautiful but serve as a comprehensive history of Mexico.  There are a lot of hidden gems in the mural such as a painting of the artist in Aztec garb, next to hsi father who taught him to paint next to his grandfather who taught him about Mexico history.  It is worth hiring a guide on the spot to give you further details.  Well worth a visit.

239154757.name: You have to see this!
239154757.author: a TripAdvisor user
239154757.reviewBody: Amazing murals done by a local artist about 10 years or so ago.  The whole history of Mexico on the walls!  I especially loved the one showing Cortez meeting Xicotencatl.

231978801.name: Tlascala\'s #1
231978801.author: a TripAdvisor user
231978801.reviewBody: There frankly not much to do in pretty, tranquil Tlascala, but what is there is solid. These exceptionally exuberant and colorful murals vividly tell the history of Tlascala. My theory is that murals were used to build a sense of national identity at a time when illiteracy was a serious problem and the nation was recovering from the upheavals of the revolution and the corruption of the Diazz regime which preceded it.

229294927.name: Don\'t miss these seeing these beautiful murals!
229294927.author: a TripAdvisor user
229294927.reviewBody: The highlight of Tlaxcala is seeing the murals in the Palacio de Gobierno created by Desiderio Hern\u00e1ndez Xochitiozin.  This talented artist was born in the state of Tlaxcala in 1922 and he passed away 2007.  These murals are his most important work as they illustrate the history of the state.  The murals were started in 1957 and he was never able to complete them before he died.  I found these murals to be just as impressive as the murals done by Diego Rivera in Mexico City.  Don\'t miss seeing them when you are in Tlaxcala!  You won\'t be disappointed!

198408697.name: Exceptional
198408697.author: a TripAdvisor user
198408697.reviewBody: Very well done and presents a vivid history of Tlaxcala from way before Cortez came to the 20th Century

194685460.name: Great stop.
194685460.author: a TripAdvisor user
194685460.reviewBody: Magnificent and overwhelming. Under restoration at present but still visible through the careful work being done. Actually interesting to see the work in progress. Worth the visit.

193600312.name: Wow!  Magnificent.  Please see
193600312.author: a TripAdvisor user
193600312.reviewBody: I was floored by the beauty and the immensity of the paintings.  The colors are vivid.  Stories told are fascinating,   I could not, and did not, want to leave.

177960155.name: Tlaxcalas History at the Government Palace
177960155.author: a TripAdvisor user
177960155.reviewBody: In 1957 Al Fresco Muralist Desiderio H. Xochitziotzin began painting his legendary mural of 450 square yards of murals on the walls of the Government Palace. In blazing colors he depicts the History of the Nation of Tlaxcala from PreColombian times up to the End of the Porfiriano Epoc.\n From 1957 till his death in 2007 Mr. Xochitziotzin could be found many weekends sitting on a scaffold painting his masterpiece. He traveled many times to the Vatican to study the Codices they have to prepare a realistic painting of Indigenous Life in Tlaxcala and to describe it\'s struggle against the Aztec Empire. Also in his painting is the legend of the founding of the corn culture, (Tlaxcala in Nahuatl language means the place of the corn bread ) and the Agave plant which Cortes described as the Tree of Wonders.\n Photos are allowed if no Flash is used, the building is open from 9 AM till 5:30 PM. It is located in Front of the Main Plaza and there are several nice Restaurants nearby. The Tlaxcala Tourist Bureau is around the corner with many helpful free brochures.

634481828.name: Beginning of Christianity
634481828.author: a TripAdvisor user
634481828.reviewBody: The cool thing is you can see the font where the first converts were baptized to the Christian faith in the New World (Cortes was their godfather), and the beautiful Mudajar ceiling.

itemReviewed.name: Catedral de Nuestra Senora de la Asuncion de Tlaxcala

645382301.name: Don\'t miss it if you\'re a fan of Mexican arts & crafts
645382301.author: a TripAdvisor user
645382301.reviewBody: The Living Museum of Folk Arts and Traditions is a space with a mission to preserve, promote and market handicrafts manufactured in the state of Tlaxcala. The museum guides are the artisans themselves.  I especially enjoyed the gallery showcasing beautiful traditional weavings from the area, as well as one with masquerade costumes. There is a small, on-site store where you can purchase some of the local handicrafts.

itemReviewed.name: Museo Vivo de Artes y Tradiciones Populares

498030386.name: Beautiful gardens and ceramics
498030386.author: a TripAdvisor user
498030386.reviewBody: The day we went the textile museum was closed for a private event, so we could only see the kitchen building and the ceramics/pottery. It was a perfect size for being able to learn about and view the ceramics from the state. The gardens within the museum area are just beautiful! I took several pictures of the unusual plants. I bought several things at the lovely gift shop.

itemReviewed.name: Museo Vivo de Artes y Tradiciones Populares

292967198.name: A must!
292967198.author: a TripAdvisor user
292967198.reviewBody: This museum is a must when coming to Tlaxcala. You can see all the traditional artesanias from the state. There are indigenous people explaining their traditions. Beautiful! Don\'t miss the sala del Pulque y agave.

itemReviewed.name: Museo Vivo de Artes y Tradiciones Populares

286835283.name: The gift shop had distilled pulque which is very similar to Mescal. Also there is a restaurant to one side of the museum
286835283.author: a TripAdvisor user
286835283.reviewBody: An excellent museum that shows you all the different types of arts and crafts of the state along with local cultural customs. From Pulque culture to textiles and silver jewelry making. Entrance fee was a modest ten pesos. The Museum also has a gift shop featuring many craftworks.  We purchased some woodcarvings and a walking cane at a very economical price.

itemReviewed.name: Museo Vivo de Artes y Tradiciones Populares

277211910.name: Small but terrific museum
277211910.author: a TripAdvisor user
277211910.reviewBody: This small museum highlights the artisans of the area, several of whom were on hand to demonstrate their craft. It has a lovely garden and superb gift shop.

itemReviewed.name: Museo Vivo de Artes y Tradiciones Populares

255242063.name: The building was a convent
255242063.author: a TripAdvisor user
255242063.reviewBody:
They have very interesting collections of prehispanic
scultures and all of them have a short explanation
from which part of Mexico are from. We visited the 
Museo, in November, and the have an special tribute
called "Altar de Ofrenda de los Muertos", which it is
very popular celebration the first days of November not
only in Tlaxcala, but in all the Mexican Country, very interesting celebration.

itemReviewed.name: Museo Vivo de Artes y Tradiciones Populares

248994136.name: Hmmm
248994136.author: a TripAdvisor user
248994136.reviewBody: I was overall disappointed with and by Tlaxcala, a pretty town, but a boring one. I\'ve been to any number of "artes populares" museums in Mexico, and loved them. This one was just so-so. Tlaxcala really needs to step up its game.

itemReviewed.name: Museo Vivo de Artes y Tradiciones Populares

672127364.name: Lindo
672127364.author: a TripAdvisor user
672127364.reviewBody: Nosotros fuimos de noche, y todo se ve\u00eda hermoso, con buena vista! No hay mucho q hacer, no encontr\u00e9 la historia del lugar.

658924342.name: Bonito. Interesante.
658924342.author: a TripAdvisor user
658924342.reviewBody: No es incre\u00edble pero si es una menci\u00f3n bonita a los h\u00e9roes de Tlaxcala desde comunidades ind\u00edgenas hasta la independencia. Vale la pena como parte del recorrido del centro.

624857335.name: Linda vista!!
624857335.author: a TripAdvisor user
624857335.reviewBody: Visita r\u00e1pida para no dejar pasar la vista del lugar , subirlas y bajarlas es divertido y algo cansado , pero vale la pena conocer las escalinatas !!

619270125.name: Que falta de inter\u00e9s por su cuidado
619270125.author: a TripAdvisor user
619270125.reviewBody: El lugar puede ofrecer tanto, una vista padr\u00edsima de toda la ciudad, seguridad, comercios cercanos y sin embargo lo \u00fanico que esperas es que no te asalten, el lugar es sucio, las fuentes y la decoraci\u00f3n maltratadas, poca iluminaci\u00f3n, falta de educaci\u00f3n por parte de los locales para brindar candidez y hospitalidad a sus visitantes..

604415716.name: Cansado...
604415716.author: a TripAdvisor user
604415716.reviewBody: Se ve toda la ciudad, de noche muy bonito es un buen lugar para salir a caminar y pasear lo recomiendo hay dos bates medio raros pero para lo cansado se puede llegar

599051726.name: Monumento para visitar en Tlaxcala
599051726.author: a TripAdvisor user
599051726.reviewBody:
Este es un monumento que no está muy lejos del centro histórico de Tlaxcala, a una cuantas cuadras, si se quiere se puede subir caminando pero son bastantes escaleras que subir, igual se puede llegar por las calles de arriba directo al mirador. 

Es un monumento con bustos de las principales figuras en la historia del país y remata con un enorme monumento a Xicohténcatl Axayacatzin. Los lugareños han adoptado el poner en el mirador candado al puro estilo Florenciano y Parisino para sellar su amor por la eternidad (aunque el rio queda un poco lejos para tirar la llave).

No tiene ningún costo y las vistas de la ciudad son inmejorables.

645380552.name: Worth a visit
645380552.author: a TripAdvisor user
645380552.reviewBody: This is a small museum located in a 16th century Franciscan convent. Its nine halls relate the historical development of the region, from the pre-Hispanic epoch to the aftermath of the Revolution. It houses a collection of pre-Hispanic objects from archeological zones neighboring the city. Unfortunately, at the time we visited, the pre-Hispanic gallery was closed due to damage from an earthquake in 2017.  However, they had a temporary exhibition of art from the Ivory Coast in Africa.

634481496.name: Okay collection
634481496.author: a TripAdvisor user
634481496.reviewBody: This is attached to the old Temple of the College--be warned this church closes from 2-4pm.  There is a nice view of the bull ring from the plaza outside and of the old tower.

360067466.name: Small but well laid out
360067466.author: a TripAdvisor user
360067466.reviewBody: An interesting collection, well labelled, but only in Spanish. I was rsp finally fascinated by the series of large paintings depicting the life of St Anthony of Padua.

310606537.name: Tlaxcala, Mexico is a hidden jewel
310606537.author: a TripAdvisor user
310606537.reviewBody: Most Americans and Canadians have never heard of Tlaxcala. They should know about it - and go visit. It\'s the smallest and least populace state in Mexico, but it\'s full of incredible things to see. The mural in the municipal building in Tlaxcala, the capital city of the state of the same name, may be one of the best I\'ve ever seen in Mexico (and this is the mural capital of the world). The oldest soccer stadium is also worth seeing, as are the numerous historic buildings. You can spend a day or more in Tlaxcala, as part of a vacation to Puebla, one of the colonial jewels of Mexico (downtown Puebla is a World Heritage site). There is more to see in Puebla and nearby Cholula than most tourists will be able to sample in a lifetime, let alone a few days of vacation. Go to this amazing part of Mexico!

255980569.name: Should the official web sites be trusted ?
255980569.author: a TripAdvisor user
255980569.reviewBody:
I hate giving a bad score, but in this case I had no other choice. The museum web site (www.inah.gob.mx, Spanish version, updated August 24, 2014) says that the museum "hosts a collection of paintings, ceramics and stone works representative of the cultural activities in the pre-columbine period and in the colonial period”. Yet, at the time of my visit, the only available display was a collection of paintings by Manuel Pastrana and nothing else. Pastrana was a painter of the late 19th century and an Academician. The paintings in exhibition are diligently polished and sugary, as one expects from an academician. The exhibit gives prominence to a large set of works portraying undressed men in statuesque or dreamy postures.

The web site also says that “the building which hosts the collections … is unique for the quality of its architecture”. Actually, the building is no more than a minuscule former convent, and I didn't detect any sign of "unique architectural quality". 

Luckily enough, I visited this museum on a Sunday, when admission is free; so I cannot complain, since I paid nothing. But a sign posted at the reception says that on the weekdays admission is 62 Pesos (about 4.3 US $): I can imagine the comments of those who are going to pay 62 Pesos for this prank.

248992122.name: Meh
248992122.author: a TripAdvisor user
248992122.reviewBody: This museum, located inside the Ex-Convento Franciscano de la Ascunsion, did not do a whole lot for me. The collection consists largely of rather dreary and typical religious art. There are better museums in Tlaxcala, a very pretty but frankly dull town.

422512409.name: Don\'t miss church murals
422512409.author: a TripAdvisor user
422512409.reviewBody: Inside the old church of San Esteban are some very old painted murals that are being restored. These are well worth a visit if you\'re interested in the history of Mexico.

238157797.name: Only if you like archeology and have time
238157797.author: a TripAdvisor user
238157797.reviewBody: Like the title says, the first time I went was because I liked archeology and had time. This is was I was\u00b4t disappointed.\nIt\u00b4s a very small site because of the catholic church. Like many of the prehispanic archeological sites that were destroyed to build their churches on top of the temples and pyramids.\nThe history of Tizatl\u00e1n is very important to the Tlaxcala\u00b4s culture, but not much is left of that.

194689186.name: TLAXCALA HISTORY
194689186.author: a TripAdvisor user
194689186.reviewBody: Fascinating story of the history of Tlaxcala based on pre-Columbian and colonial texts painted on the walls and arches.

177828229.name: Tizatlan Military Headquarters of the Tlaxcallan Nation
177828229.author: a TripAdvisor user
177828229.reviewBody: Someone said this is a small site and yes it\'s small but it\'s very Historical. When Cortes came here it was the main location of the Tlaxcalan leader Xicohtencatl. In fact the Church of St. Stephen which is there now was built from stones of the former Palace. This was a military training School for warriors of Tlaxcala. The Church has an open Chapel and interesting paintings from the 16th Century.  The Town has many craftsmen who specialize in woodcarving and they are well known for making excellent walking canes.

145858528.name: Small, small, small
145858528.author: a TripAdvisor user
145858528.reviewBody: Close to Tlaxcala.  You can drive right up to the site.  Easy walk.  There is a early church on the sight that is under restoration.  And, it\'s free.

292967688.name: Small but good
292967688.author: a TripAdvisor user
292967688.reviewBody: This is a small museum but shows a lot of the history of Tlaxcala as well as traditional crafts. The embroidered shirts and the rebozos are worth looking at.

244870754.name: Small well located museum with some nice artifacts
244870754.author: a TripAdvisor user
244870754.reviewBody: The museum is located adjacent to the zocalo so it could not be easier to find.  The admission fee is only 15 pesos or apx. one US dollar so what do you have to loose.  You can spend an interesting 15 minutes here.

579546507.name: Experiencia de 10!!!
579546507.author: a TripAdvisor user
579546507.reviewBody: Excelente lugar, muy limpio, familiar, ambiente agradable, la comida deliciosa y precios muy accesibles.  \nRecomiendo el at\u00fan sellado.

403426112.name: Visita obligada
403426112.author: a TripAdvisor user
403426112.reviewBody: Colecci\u00f3n bien montada, sin duda un lugar para aprender mas y conocer sobre la historia. Debes de visitarlo!

address.streetAddress: Av. Independencia Av. Guerrero, Col. Tlaxcala Centro

320449882.name: Un gran homenaje al gran dramaturgo Tlaxcalense
320449882.author: a TripAdvisor user
320449882.reviewBody: Una sensacional y \u00fanica  experiencia en mi recorrido por este museo inaugurado apenas hace una semana, muy muy recomendable.  Resultar\u00e1 grato para todos, pero en especial ser\u00e1 enriquecedor para aquellos que como yo amamos la literatura, la poes\u00eda, las artes.  El museo documenta la vida y obra del gran dramaturgo Tlaxcalense Miguel N. Lira cuya obra ("La Escondida", "Antes del final", entre otras) fuera llevada a la pantalla en la \u00e9poca dorada del cine mexicano, obra que evoca y enaltece la vida rural Mexicana y a Tlaxcala, la patria chica; con sus costumbres, sus tradiciones, sus cantos, sus paisajes y sus ritos. El museo est\u00e1 montado de una forma tan art\u00edstica emocional que te puede hacer brotar l\u00e1grimas de emoci\u00f3n, quien lo dise\u00f1\u00f3 hizo una bell\u00edsima selecci\u00f3n de fragmentos de su obra que adem\u00e1s disfrutas a cada paso que des provocando la activaci\u00f3n autom\u00e1tica de videos, grabaciones, m\u00fasica \u00f3 acudiendo a los auriculares y tabletas colocadas sobre las paredes.  Miguel N. Lira tuvo una gran partucipaci\u00f3n en la vida pol\u00edtica nacional a la par de su actividad literaria y po\u00e9tica lo cual hizo dirigir la vista y poner en primer plano al Estado de Tlaxcala, muy merecido.

address.streetAddress: Av. Independencia Av. Guerrero, Col. Tlaxcala Centro

651920735.name: Un espacio para disfrutar y relajarte
651920735.author: a TripAdvisor user
651920735.reviewBody: El jardin botanico es un espacio que rescata un poco de natuarleza, ya que presenta areas dedicadas a los diferentes tipos de vegetacion de Tlaxcala. Cuenta con plantas del semidesierto y de bosques templados. Tiene un invernadero de plantas tropicales que desgraciadamente han descuidado y lleva tiempo en el abandono casi total, es una lastima.El jardin tiene veredas y andadores muy agradables y faciles de caminar, accesible para discapacitados. Tiene una sala de cine de arte, que es una muy buena alternativa en Tlaxcala. Cuenta con areas para picnic. El teatro al aire libre esta fatal!, rompe con el paisaje verde tan agradable, no se como se les ocurrio, pero fuera de eso es muy recomendable para disfrutar un fin de semana en Tlaxcala.\n

203168908.name: Interesting view of history.
203168908.author: a TripAdvisor user
203168908.reviewBody: There are a lot of reproductions here, but still it\'s really interesting to get the history of the native peoples and the Spanish in Tlaxcala.

itemReviewed.name: Museo de la Memoria de Tlaxcala

190942197.name: Worth a stop
190942197.author: a TripAdvisor user
190942197.reviewBody: I visited here while in Tlaxcala a few months ago.  The exhibits were interesting enough- worth popping in if you\'re in town.

itemReviewed.name: Museo de la Memoria de Tlaxcala
